editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The revengers tragedy. As it hath been sundry times acted, by the King's majesty's servants.
At London printed by G. eld, and are to be fold at his house in Fleet-lane at the sign of the printers-press. 1607.

div.head: The revengers tragedy.
Act. 1. scae. 1.
div.stage: Enter Vendici, the Duke, Duchess, Lusurioso her son, Spurio the bastard, with a train, pass over the stage with torchlight.

sp.speaker: Vindi.
sp.l: Duke: royal lecher; go, grey haired adultery,
And thou his son as impious steeped as he:
And thou his bastard true-beget in evil:
And thou his Duchess that will do with devil,
Four exc'llent characters — oh that marrowless age,
Would stuff the hollow bones with damned desires,
And stead of heat kindle infernal fires,
Within the spendthrift veins of a dry Duke,
A parched and juiceless luxur. O God! one
That has scarce blood enough to live upon.
And he to ryct it like a son and heir?
O the thought of that
Turns my abused heartstrings into fret.
Thou sallow picture of my poisoned love,
My study's ornament, thou shell of death,
Once the bright face of my betrothed lady,
When life and beauty naturally filled out
These ragged imperfections;
When two-heaven-pointed diamonds were set
In those unsightly rings; — then 'twas a face
So far beyond the artificial shine
Of any woman's bought complexion
That the uprightest man, (If such there be,
That sin but seven times a day) broke custom
And made up eight with looking after her,
O she was able to ha' made a usurer's son
Melt all his patrimony in a kiss,
And what his father fifty years told
To have consumed, and yet his suit been cold:
But o accursed palace!
Thee when thou wert apparelled in thy flesh,
The old Duke poisoned,
Because thy purer part would not consent
unto his palsy-lust, for old men lustful
Do show like young men angry, eager violent,
Outbid like their limited performances
Oh beware an old man hot, and vicious

l.quote: Age as in gold in lust is covetous.

sp.l: Vengeance thou murders quitrent, and whereby
Thou showst thyself tenant to tragedy,
O keep thy day, hour, minute, I beseech,
For those thou hast determined: hum: who ere knew
Murder unpaid, faith give revenge her due
Sha's kept touch hitherto — be merry, merry,
Advance thee, oh thou terror to fat folks
To have their costly three-piled flesh worn of
As bare as this — for banquets: ease and laughter,
Can make great men as greatness goes by clay,
But wise men little are more great than they?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Still sighing o'er death's vizard.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Brother welcome,
What comfort bringst thou? how go things at court?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: In silk and silver brother: never braver.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Puh,
Thou play'st upon my meaning prithee say
Has that bald madam, opportunity?
Yet thought upon's, speak are we happy yet?
Thy wrongs and mine are for one scabbard fit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It may prove happiness?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: What is't may prove?
Give me to taste.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Give me your hearing then,
You know my place at court.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I; the Duke's chamber
But 'tis a marvel thou'rt not turned out yet!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith I have been shooud at, but 'twas still my hap
To hold by'th Duchess skirt, you guess at that,
Whom such a coat keeps up can ne'er fall flat,
But to the purpose.
Last evening predecessor unto this,
the Duke's son warily enquired for me,
Whose pleasure I attended: he began,
By policy to open and unhusk me
About the time and common rumour:
But I had so much wit to keep my thoughts
Up in their built houses, yet afforded him
An idle satisfaction without danger,
But the whole aim, and scope of his intent
Ended in this, conjuring me in private,
To seek some strange digested fellow forth:
Of ill-contented nature, either disgraced
In former times, or by new grooms displaced,
Since his stepmother's nuptials, such a blood
A man that were for evil only good;
To give you the true word some base coined pander?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I reach you, for I know his heat is such,
Were there as many concubines as ladies
He would not be contained, he must fly out:
I wonder how ill featured, vild proportioned.
That one should be: if she were made for woman,
Whom at the insurrection of his lust
He would refuse for once, heart, I think none,
Next to a skull, though more unsound than one
Each face he meets he strongly dotes upon.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother you've truly spoke him?
He knows not you, but I'll swear you know him.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: And therefore I'll put on that knave for once,
And be a right man then, a man a'th time,
For to be honest is not to be ith' world,
Brother I'll be that strange composed fellow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And I'll prefer you brother.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Go too then,
The small'st advantage fattens wronged men
It may point out, occasion, if I meet her,
I'll hold her by the foretop fast enough;
Or like the French mole heave up hair and all,
I have a habit that will fit it quaintly,
Here comes our mother.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And sister.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: We must quoin.
Women are apt you know to take false money,
But I dare stake my soul for these two creatures
Only excuse excepted that they'll swallow,
Because their sex is easy in belief.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: What news from cour son Carlo?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith mother,
'Tis whispered there the Duchess youngest son
Has played a rape on lord Antonio's wife.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: On that religious lady!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Royal blood: monster he deserves to die,
If Italy had no more hopes but he.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Sister you've sentenced most direct, and true,
The laws a woman, and would she were you:
Mother I must take leave of you.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Leave for what?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I intend speedy travail.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That he does madam.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Speedy indeed!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: For since my worthy father's funeral,
My life's unnaturally to me, e'en compelled
As if I hued now when I should be dead.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Indeed he was a worthy gentleman
Had his estate been fellow to his mind.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The Duke did much deject him.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Much?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: To much.
And through disgrace oft smothered in his spirit,
When it would mount, surely I think he died
Of discontent: the nobleman's consumption.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Most sure he did!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Did he? lack, — you know all
You were his midnight secretary.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: No.
He was too wise to trust me with his thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I'faith then father thou wast wise indeed,

l.quote: Wives are but made to go to bed and feed.

sp.l: Come mother, sister: you'll bring me onward brother?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I'll quickly turn into another.

div.stage: Enter the old Duke, Lussiurioso, his son, the Duchess; the bastard, the Duchess two sons Ambitioso, and Superuacuo, the third her youngest brought out with officers for the rape two judges.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Duchess it is your youngest son, we're sorry,
His violent act has e'en drawn blood of honour
And stained our honours,
Thrown ink upon the forehead of our state
Which envious spirits will dip their pens into
After our death; and blot us in our tombs.
For that which would seem treason in our lives
Is laughter when we're dead, who dares now whisper
That dares not then speak out, and e'en proclaim,
With loud words and broad pens our closest shame.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Your grace hath spoke like to your silver years
Full of confirmed gravity; — for what is it to have,
A flattering false insculption on a tomb:
And in men's hearts reproach, the bowelled corpse,
May be seared in, but with free tongue I speak,

l.quote: The faults of great men through their fierce clothes break,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: They do, we're sorry for't, it is our fate,
To live in fear and die to live in hate,
I leave him to your sentence dome him lords
The fact is great; whilst I sit by and sigh.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My gracious lord I pray be merciful,
Although his trespass far exceed his years,
Think him to be your own as I am yours,
Call him not son in law: the law I fear
Will fall too soon upon his name and him:
Temper his fault with pity?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Good my lord.
Then 'twill not taste so bitter and unpleasant
Upon the judge's palate, for offences
Gilt o'er with mercy, show like fairest women,
Good only for their beauties, which washed of: no sin is ouglies ambitis I beseech your grace,
Be soft and mild, let not relentless law,
look with an iron forehead on our brother.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: He yields small comfort yet, hope he shall die,
And if a bastard's wish might stand in force,
Would all the court were turn de into a corse,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No pity yet? must I rise fruitless then,
A wonder in a woman; are my knees,
Of such low — mettle — that without respect —

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Let the offender stand forth,
'Tis the Duke's pleasure that impartial doom,
Shall take first hold of his unclean attempt,
A rape! why 'tis the very core of lust,
Double adultery.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Jud.
sp.l: And which was worse,
Committed on the lord Antonio's wife,
That general honest lady, confess my lord!
What moved you to't?

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Why flesh and blood my lord.
What should move men unto a woman else,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: O do not jest thy doom, trust not an axe
Or sword too far; the law is a wise serpent
And quickly can beguile thee of thy life,
Though marriage only has made thee my brother,
I love thee so far, play not with thy death,

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: I thank you troth, good admonitions faith,
If the grace now to make use of them,

sp.speaker: 1. Jud.
sp.l: That lady's name has spread such a fair wing
Over all Italy; that if our tongues,
Were sparing towards the fact, judgement itself,
Would be condemned and suffer in men's thoughts,

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Well then 'tis done, and it would please me well
Were it to do again: sure she's a goddess,
For I'd no power to see her, and to live,
It falls out true in this for I must die,
Her beauty was ordained to be my scaffold,
And yet my thinks I might be easier ceased,
My fault being sport, let me but die in jest,

sp.speaker: 1. Jud.
sp.l: This be the sentence,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O kept upon your tongue, let it not slip,
Death too soon steals out of a lawyer's lip,
Be not so cruel-wise?

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Your grace must pardon us,
'Tis but the justice of the law.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The law,
Is grown more subtle than a woman should be.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Now, now he dies, rid 'em away.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O what it is to have an old-cool Duke,
To be as slack in tongue, as in performance.

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Confirmed, this be the doom irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Tomorrow early.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pray be a-bed my lord.

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Your grace much wrongs yourself.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: No 'tis that tongue,
Your too much right, dos do us too much wrong.

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: Let that offender —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Live, and be in health.

sp.speaker: 1. jud
sp.l: Be on a scaffold

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hold, hold, my lord.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Pax on't,
What makes my dad speak now?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We will defer the judgement till next sitting,
In the mean time let him be kept close prisoner:
Guard bear him hence.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: Brother, this makes for thee,
Fear not, we'll have a trick to set thee free.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Brother, I will expect it from you both; and in that hope I rest.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Farewell, be merry.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Delayed, deferred nay than if judgement have cold blood,
Flattery and bribes will kill it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: About it then my lords with your best powers,
More serious business calls upon our homes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Wast ever known step-duchess was so mild,
And calm as I? some now would plot his death,
With easy doctors, those loose living men,
And make his withered grace fall to his grave,
And keep church better?
Some second wife would do this, and dispatch
her double loathed lord at meat and sleep,
Indeed 'tis true an old man's twice a child,
Mine cannot speak, one of his single words,
Would quite have freed my youngest dearest son
From death or durance, and have made him walk
With a bold foot upon the thorny law,
Whose prickles should bow under him, but 'tis not,
And therefore wedlock faith shall be forgotten,
I'll kill him in his forehead, hate there feed,
That wound is deepest though it never bleed:
And here comes he whom my heart points unto,
His bastard son, but my love's true-beget,
Many a wealthy letter have I sent him,
Swelled up with jewels, and the timorous man
Is yet but coldly kind,
That jewel's mine that quivers in his ear,
Mocking his master's chillness and vain fear,
Has spied me now.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Madam? your grace so private.
My duty on your hand.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Upon my hand sir, troth I think you'd fear,
To kiss my hand too if my lip stood there,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Witness I would not madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis a wonder,
For ceremony has made many fools,
It is as easy way unto a Duchess,
As to a hatted-dame, (If her love answer)
But that by timorous honours, pale respects,
Idle degrees of fear, men make their ways
Hard of themselves — what have you thought of me?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Madam I ever think of you, in duty,
Regard and —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Puh, upon my love I mean.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: I would 'twere love, but 'Tus a fouler name
Than lust; you are my father's wife, your grace may guess now,
What I could call it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why thou'rt his son but falsely,
'Tis a hard question whether he begotten thee.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: I'faith 'tis true too; I'm an uncertain man,
sp.p: Of more uncertain woman; may be his groom a'th' stable begotten me, you know I know not, he could ride a horse well, a shroud suspicion marry — he was wondrous tall, he had his length i'faith, for peeping over half shut holiday windows,
sp.l: Men would desire him light, when he was a foot,
He made a goodly show under a penthouse,
And when he rid, his hat would check the signs, and clatter
Barber's basins.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Nay set you a horse back once,
You'll ne'er light off.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Indeed I am a beggar.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That's more the sign thou'rt great — but to our love.
Let it stand firm both in thought and mind,
That the Duke was thy father, as no doubt then
He bid fair fort, thy injury is the more,
For had he cut thee a right diamond,
Thou hadst been next set in the dukedom's ring,
When his worn self like ages easy slave,
Had dropped out of the collet into th' grave;
What wrong can equal this? canst thou be tame
And think upon't.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: No mad and think upon't.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who would not be revenged of such a father,
E'en in the worst way? I would thank that sin,
That could most injury him, and be in league with it,
O what a grief 'tis, that a man should live
But once ith' world, and then to live a bastard,
The curse a'the womb, the thief of nature,
Begotten against the seventh commandment,
Half damned in the conception, by the justice
Of that unbribed everlasting law.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: O I'd a hot-backed devil to my father.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Would not this mad e'en patience, make blood rough?
Who but an eunuch would not sin? his bed
By one false minute disinherited.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Ay, there's the vengeance that my birth was wrapped in,
I'll be revenged for all, now hate begin,
I'll call foul incest but a venial sin.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Cold still: in vain then must a Duchess woo?

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Madam I blush to say what I will do.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thence flew sweet comfort, earnest and farewell.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: O one incestuous kiss picks open hell.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Faith now old Duke; my vengeance shall reach high,
I'll arm thy brow with woman's heraldry.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Duke, thou didst do me wrong, and by thy act
Adultery is my nature;
Faith if the truth were known, I was begotten
After some gluttonous dinner, some stirring dish
Was my first father; when deep healths went round,
And ladies' cheeks were painted red with wine,
Their tongues as short and nimble as their heels
Uttering words sweet and thick; and when they rise,
Were merrily disposed to fall again,
In such a whispering and withdrawing hour,
When base-male-bawds kept sentinel at stairhead
Was I stolen softly; o — damnation met
The sin of feasts, drunken adultery.
I feel it swell me; my revenge is just,
I was begotten in impudent wine and lust:
Stepmother I consent to thy desires,
I love thy mischief well, but I hate thee,
And those three cubs thy sons, wishing confusion
Death and disgrace may be their epitaphs,
As for my brother the Duke's only son,
Whose birth is more beholding to report
Than mine, and yet perhaps as falsely sown.
(Women must not be trusted with their own)
I'll lose my days upon him hate all I,
Duke on thy brow I'll draw my bastardy.
For indeed a bastard by nature should make cuckolds,
Because he is the son of a cuckold-maker.

div.stage: Enter Vindici and Hippolito, Vindici in disguise to attend l. Lussurioso the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: What brother? am I far enough from myself?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: As if another man had been sent whole
into the world, and none wist how he came.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: It will confirm me bold: the child a th' court,
Let blushes dwell i'th country impudence!
Thou goddess of the palace, mistress of mistresses
To whom the costly perfumed-people pray,
Strike thou my forehead into dauntless marble;
Mine eyes to steady saphires: turn my visage,
And if I must needs glow, let me blush inward
That this immodest season may not spy,
That scholar in my cheeks, fool bashfulness.
That maid in the old time, whose flush of grace
Would never suffer her to get good clothes;
Our maids are wiser; and are less ashamed,
Save grace the bawd I seldom hear grace named!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay brother you reach out a'th verge now, — sfoot the Duke's son, settle your looks.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Pray let me not be doubted.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My lord —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Hipolito? — be absent leave us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My lord after long search, wary inquiries
And politic siftings, I made choice of yond fellow,
Whom I guess rare for many deep employments;
This our age swims within him: and if time
Had so much hair, I should take him for time,
He is so near kin to this present minute?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: 'Tis enough.
We thank thee: yet words are but great-men's blanks
Gold though it be dumb does utter the best thanks.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your plenteous honour — an exc'llent fellow my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: So, give us leave — welcome, be not far off, we must be better acquainted, push, be bold with us, thy hand:

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: With all my heart i'faith how dost sweet musk-cat.
When shall we lie together?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Wondrous knave!
Gather him into boldness, sfoot the slave's
Already as familiar as an ague,
And shakes me at his pleasure, friend I can
Forget myself in private, but else where,
I pray do you remember me.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O very well sir — I construe myself saucy!

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What hast been,
Of what profession.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: A bonesetter!

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: A bonesetter!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: A bawd my lord,
One that sets bones together.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Notable bluntness?
Fit, fit for me, e'en trained up to my hand
Thou hast been scrivener to much knavery then.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Fool, to abundance sir; I have been witness
To the surrenders of a thousand virgins,
And not so little,
I have seen patrimonies washed a pieces
Fruit-fields turned into bastards,
And in a world of acres,
Not so much dust due to the heir was left too
As would well gravel a petition

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Fine villain? troth I like him wondrously
He's e'en shaped for my purpose, than thou knowest
Ith' world strange lust.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O Dutch lust! fulsome lust!
Drunken procreation, which begets, so many drunkards;
Some father dreads not (Gone to bed in wine) to slide from the mother,
And cling the daughter-in-law,
Some uncles are adulterous with their nieces,
Brothers with brother's wives, oh hour of incest!
Any kin now next to the rim ath' sister
Is man's meat in these days, and in the morning
When they are up and dressed, and their mask on,
Who can perceive this? save that eternal eye
That see's through flesh and all, well: — if any thing be damned?
It will be twelve o'clock at night; that twelve
Will never scape;
It is the Judas of the hours; wherein,
Honest salvation is betrayed to sin,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Introth it is too? but let this talk glide
It is our blood to err, though hell gaped loud
ladies know Lucifer fell, yet still are proud!
Now sir? wert thou as secret as thou'rt subtle,
And deeply fathomed into all estates
I would embrace thee for a near employment,
And thou shouldst swell in money, and be able
To make lame beggars crouch to thee.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My lord?
Secret? I ne'er had that disease ath' mother
I praise my father: why are men made close?
But to keep thoughts in best, I grant you this
Tell but some woman a secret over night,
Your doctor may find it in the urinal ith' morning,
But my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: So, thou'rt confirmed in me
And thus I enter thee.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: This Indian devil,
Will quickly enter any man: but a usurer,
He prevents that, by entering the devil first.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Attend me, I am past my depth in lust
And I must swim or drown, all my desires
Are levelled at a virgin not far from court,
To whom I have conveyed by messenger
Many waxed lines, full of my neatest spirit,
And jewels that were able to ravish her
Without the help of man; all which and more
She foolish chaste sent back, the messengers,
Receiving frowns for answers.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Possible!
'Tis a rare phoenix who ere she be,
If your desires be such, she so repugnant,
In troth my lord I'd be revenged and marry her.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Push; the dowry of her blood and of her fortunes,
Are both too mean, — good enough to be bad withal
I'm one of that number can defend
Marriage is good: yet rather keep a friend,
Give me my bed by stealth — there's true delight
What breeds a loathing in't, but night by night.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: A very fine religion?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Therefore thus,
He trust thee in the business of my heart
Because I see thee well experienced
In this luxurious day wherein we breath,
Go thou, and with a smooth enchanting tongue
Bewitch her ears, and cousin her of all grace
Enter upon the portion of her soul,
Her honour, which she calls her chastity
And bring it into expense, for honesty
Is like a stock of money laid to sleep,
Which ne'er so little broke, does never keep:

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: You have gint the tang i'faith my lord
Make known the lady to me, and my brain,
Shall swell with strange invention: I will move it
Till I expire with speaking, and drop down
Without a word to save me; — but I'll work —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: We thank thee, and will raise thee: — receive her name, it is the only daughter, to madam Gratiana the late widow

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O, my sister, my sister? —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Why dost walk aside?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My lord, I was thinking how I might begin
As thus, o lady — or twenty hundred devices,
Her very bodkin will put a man in.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Ay, or the wagging of her hair.

sp.speaker: Vind
sp.l: No, that shall put you in my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Shalt? why content, dost know the daughter then?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O exc'llent well by sight.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: That was her brother
That did prefer thee to us.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My lord I think so,
I knew I had seen him somewhere —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: And therefore prithee let thy heart to him,
Be as a virgin, close.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O me good lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: We may laugh at that simple age within him;

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Himself being made the subtle instrument,
To wind up a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That's I my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: That's thou.
To entice and work his sister.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: A pure novice?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Was finely managed.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Gallantly carried;
A pretty-perfumed villain.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I've bethought me
If she prove chaste still and immovable,
Venture upon the mother, and with gifts
As I will furnish thee, begin with her.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O fie, fie, that's the wrong end my lord. 'tis mere impossible that a mother by any gifts should become a bawd to her own daughter!

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: Nay then I see thou'rt but a puny in the subtle mystery of a woman: — why 'tis held now no dainty dish: the name
sp.l: Is so in league with age, that now adays
It does eclipse three quarters of a mother;

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Dost so my lord?
Let me alone then to eclipse the fourth.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: Why well said, come I'll furnish thee, but first swear to be true in all.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: True?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Nay but swear!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Swear? — I hope your honour little doubts my faith.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Yet for my humour's sake cause I love swearing.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Cause you love swearing, 'slud I will.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Why enough,
Erelong look to be made of better stuff.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That will do well indeed my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Attend me?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Oh.
Now let me burst, I've eaten noble poison,
We are made strange fellows, brother, innocent villains,
Wilt not be angry when thou hearst on't, thinkst thou?
I'faith thou shalt; swear me to foul my sister.
Sword I durst make a promise of him to thee,
Thou shalt dis-heir him, it shall be thine honour,
And yet now angry froth is down in me,
It would not prove the meanest policy
In this disguise to try the faith of both,
Another might have had the self same office,
some slave, that would have wrought effectually,
I and perhaps o'erwrought 'em, therefore I,
Being thought travailed, will apply myself,
Unto the self same form, forget my nature,
As if no part about me were kin to 'em,
So touch 'em, — though I durst a most for good,
Venture my lands in heaven upon their good.

div.stage: Enter the discontented lord Antonio, whose wife the Duchess's youngest son ravished he discovering the body of her dead to certain lords: and Hippolito.

sp.speaker: L. Ant.
sp.l: Draw nearer lords and be sad witnesses
Of a fair comely building newly fallen,
Being falsely undermined: violent rape
Has played a glorious act, behold my lords
A sight that strikes man out of me:

sp.speaker: Piero
sp.l: That virtuous lady

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Precedent for wives?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The blush of many women, whose chaste presence,
Would e'en call shame up to their cheeks,
And make pale wanton sinners have good colours. —

sp.speaker: L. Ant.
sp.l: Dead!
Her honour first drunk poison, and her life,
Being fellows in one house did pledge her honour,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: O grief of many!

sp.speaker: L. Anto.
sp.l: I marked not this before.
A prayer book the pillow to her cheek,
This was her rich confection, and another
Plastered in her right hand, with a leaf tucked up,
Pointing to these words.
Melius virtute mori, quam per dedecus vivere.
True and effectual it is indeed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My lord since you invite us to your sorrows,
Let's truly taste 'em, that with equal comfort,
As to ourselves we may relieve your wrongs,
We have grief too, that yet walks without tongue,
Curaeleves loquuntur, maiores stupent.

sp.speaker: L. Ant.
sp.l: You deal with truth my lord.
Lend me but your attentions, and I'll cut
Long grief into short words: last revelling night.
When torchlight made an artificial noon
About the court, some courtiers in the mask,
Putting on better faces than their own,
Being full of fraud and flattery: amongst whom,
The Duchess's youngest son (That moth to honour)
Filled up a room; and with long lust to eat,
Into my wearing; amongst all the ladies,
Singled out that dear form; whoever lived,
As cold in lust as she is now in death;
(Which that step Duchess — monster knew to well;)
And therefore in the height of all the revels,
When music was hard loudest, courtiers busiest,
And ladies great with laughter; — oh vicious minute!
Unfit but for relation to be spoke of,
Then with a face more impudent than his vizard
He harried her amid a throng of panders,
That live upon damnation of both kinds,
And fed the ravenous vulture of his lust,
(Oh death to think on't) she her honour forest,
Deemed it a nobler dowry for her name,
To die with poison then to live with shame.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A wondrous lady; of rare fire compact,
Sh'as made her name an empress by that act,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: My lord what judgement follows the offender?

sp.speaker: L. Ant
sp.l: Faith none my lord it cools and is deferred,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Delay the doom for rape?

sp.speaker: L. Ant,
sp.l: O you must note who 'tis should die,
The Duchess son, she'll look to be a saver,

l.quote: Judgement in this age is never kin to favour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay then step forth thou bribeless officer;
I bind you all in steel to bind you surely,
Here let your oaths meet, to be kept and paid,
Which else will stick like rust, and shame the blade,
Strengthen my vow, that if at the next sitting,
Judgement speak all in gold, and spare the blood
Of such a serpent, e'en before their seats,
To let his soul out, which long since was found,
Guilty in heaven.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We swear it and will act it,

sp.speaker: L. Anto.
sp.l: Kind gentlemen, I thank you in mine ire,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Twere pity?
The ruins of so fair a monument,
Should not be dipped in the defacer's blood,

sp.speaker: Piero.
sp.l: Her funeral shall be wealthy, for her name,
Merits a tomb of pearl; my lord Antonio,
For this time wipe your lady from your eyes,
No doubt our grief and yours may one day court it,
When we are more familiar with revenge,

sp.speaker: L. Anto.
sp.l: That is my comfort gentlemen, and I joy,
In this one happiness above the rest,
Which will be called a miracle at last,
That being an old — man I'd a wife so chaste.

div.head: Actus. 2. scae. 1.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How hardly shall that maiden be beset,
Whose only fortunes, are her constant thoughts,
That has no other child-part but her honour,
That keeps her low; and empty in estate.
Maids and their honours are like poor beginners,
Were not sin rich there would be fewer sinners;
Why had not virtue a revenue? well,
I know the cause, 'twould have impoverished hell.
How now Dondolo.

sp.speaker: Don. madonna,
sp.p: There is one as they say a thing of flesh and blood, a man I take him by his beard that would very desirously month to mouth with you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Show his teeth in your company,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I understand thee not;

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why speak with you madonna!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Why say so madman, and cut of a great deal of dirty way; had it not been better spoke in ordinary words that one would speak with me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, that's as ordinary as two shillings, I would strive
a little to show myself in my place, a gentleman-usher scorns to use the phrase and fancy of a servingman.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yours be your one sir, go direct him hither,
I hope some happy tidings from my brother,
That lately travailed, whom my soul affects.
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Lady the best of wishes to your sex.
Fair skins and new gowns,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O they shall thank you sir,
Whence this,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O from a dear and worthy friend, mighty!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The Duke's son!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Receive that!
sp.stage: A box ath' ear to her brother.
sp.l: I swore I'd put anger in my hand,
And pass the virgin limits of myself,
To him that next appeared in that base office,
To be his sin's attorney, bear to him,
That figure of my hate upon thy check
Whilst 'tis yet hot, and I'll reward thee fort,
Tell him my honour shall have a rich name,
When several harlots shall share his with shame,
Farewell commend me to him in my hate!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is the sweetest box,
That ere my nose came nigh,
The finest drawn-work cuff that ere was worn,
I'll love this blow for ever, and this cheek
Shall still hence forward take the wall of this.
O I'm a 'bove my tongue: most constant sister,
In this thou hast right honourable shown,
Many are called by their honour that have none,
Thou art approved for ever in my thoughts.
It is not in the power of words to taint thee,
And yet for the salvation of my oath,
As my resolve in that point; I will lay,
Hard siege unto my mother, though I know,
a Siren's tongue could not bewitch her so.
Mass fitly here she comes, thanks my disguise,
Madam good afternoon.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: You're welcome sir?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The next of Italy commends him to you,
Our mighty expectation, the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I think myself much honoured, that he pleases,
To tanck me in his thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: So may you lady:
One that is like to be our sudden Duke,
The crown gapes for him every tide, and then
Commander o'er us all, do but think on him,
How blessed were they now that could pleasure him
E'en with any thing almost.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Ay, save their honour?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Tut, one would let a little of that go too
And ne'er be seen in't: ne'er be seen it, mark you,
I'd wink and let it go —

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Marry but I would not.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Marry but I would I hope, I know you would too,
If you'd that blood now which you gave your daughter,
To her indeed 'tis, this wheel comes about,
That man that must be all this, perhaps ere morning
(For his white father does but mould away)
Has long desired your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Desired?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay but he are me,
He desires now that will command hereafter,
There fore be wise, I speak as more a friend
To you then him; madam, I know you're poor,
And lack the day, there are too many poor ladies already
Why should you vex the number? 'tis despised,
Live wealthy, rightly understand the world,
And chide away that foolish — country girl
Keeps company with your daughter, chastity,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O fie, fie, the riches of the world cannot hire a mother to such a most unnatural task.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: No, but a thousand angels can,
Men have no power, angels must work you to't,
the world descends into such base-born evils
That forty angels can make fourscore devils,
There will be fools still I perceive, still fool.
Would I be poor dejected, scorned of greatness,
Swept from the palace, and see other daughters
Spring with the dew ath' court, having mine own
So much desired and loved — by the Duke's son,
No, I would raise my state upon her breast
And call her eyes my tenants, I would count
My yearly maintenance upon her cheeks:
Take coach upon her lip, and all, her parts
Should keep men after men, and I would ride,
In pleasure upon pleasure:
You took great pains for her, once when it was,
Let her requite it now, though it be but some
You brought her forth, she may well bring you home,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O heavens! this overcomes me?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Not I hope, already?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: It is too strong for me, men know that know us,
We are so weak their words can overthrow us,
He touched me nearly made my virtues bate
When his tongue struck upon my poor estate.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I e'en quake to proceed, my spirit turns edge?
I fear me she's unmother, yet I'll venture,

l.quote: That woman is all male, whom none can enter?

sp.l: What think you now lady, speak are you wiser?
What said advancement to you: thus it said!
The daughters fall lifts up the mother's head:
Did it not madam? but I'll swear it does
In many places, tut, this age fears no man,

l.quote: 'Tis no shame to be bad, because 'tis common.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I that's the comfort on't.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The comfort on't!
I keep the best for last, can these persuade you
To forget heaven — and —

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I these are they?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: That enchant our sex,
These are the means that govern our affections, — that woman
will not be troubled with the mother long,
That sees the comfortable shine of you,
I blush to think what for your sakes I'll do!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O suffering heaven with thy invisible finger,
E'en at this instant turn the precious side
Of both mine eyeballs inward, not to see myself,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Look you sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Holla.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Let this thank your pains.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O you're a kind madman;

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I'll see how I can move,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Your words will sting,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: If she be still chaste I'll ne'er call her mine,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Spoken truer than you meant it,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Daughter Castiza.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Madam,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O she's yonder.
Meet her: troops of celestial soldiers guard her heart.
Yond dam has devils enough to take her part,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Madam what makes yond evil officed man,
In presence of you;

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He lately brought
Immodest writing sent from the Duke's son
To tempt me to dishonourable act,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Dishonourable act? — good honourable fool,
That wouldst be honest cause thou wouldst be so,
Producing no one reason but thy will.
And t'as a good report, prettily commended,
But pray by whom; mean people; ignorant people,
The better sort I'm sure cannot abide it,
And by what rule shouldst we square out our lives,
But by our betters actions? o if thou knew'st
What 'twere to lose it, thou would never keep it:
But there's a cold curse laid upon all maids,
Whilst other clip the sun they clasp the shades!
Virginity is paradise, locked up.
You cannot come by yourselves without fee.
And 'twas decreed that man should keep the key!
Deny advancement, treasure, the Duke's son,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I cry you mercy. Lady I mistook you,
pray did you see my mother; which way went you?
Pray God I have not lost her.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Prettily put by.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Are you as proud to me as coy to him?
Do you not know me now?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why are you she?
The worlds so changed, one shape into another,
It is a wise child now that knows her mother?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Most right i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: I owe your cheek my hand,
For that presumption now, but I'll forget it,
Come you shall leave those childish haviours,
And understand your time, fortunes flow to you,
What will you be a girl?
If all feared drowning, that spy waves ashore,
Gold would grow rich, and all the merchant's poor.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is a pretty saying of a wicked one, but methinks now
It dos not show so well out of your mouth,
Better in his.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Faith bad enough in both,
Were I in earnest as I'll seem no less?
I wonder lady your own mother's words,
Cannot be taken, nor stand in full force.
'Tis honesty you urge; what's honesty?
'Tis but heaven's beggar; and what woman is so foolish to keep honesty,
And be not able to keep herself? No,
Times are grown wiser and will keep less charge,
A maid that has small portion now intends,
To break up house, and live upon her friends
How blessed are you, you have happiness alone,
Others must fall to thousands, you to one,
Sufficient in himself to make your forehead
Dazzle the world with jewels, and petitionary people
Start at your presence.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: O if I were young, I should be ravished.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I to lose your honour.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Slid how can you lose your honour?
To deal with my lords grace,
He'll add more honour to it by his title,
Your mother will tell you how.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: That I will.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O think upon the pleasure of the palace,
Secured ease and state; the stirring meats,
Ready to move out of the dishes, that e'en now quicken when their eaten,
Banquets abroad by torchlight, musics, sports,
Bareheaded vassals, that had ne'er the fortune
To keep on their own hats, but let horns were 'em,
Nine coaches waiting — hurry, hurry, hurry.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I to the devil.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I to the devil, toth' Duke by my faith.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I to the Duke: daughter you'd scorn to think ath'
Devil and you were there once.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: True, for most there are as proud as he for his heart i'faith
Who'd sit at home in a neglected room,
Dealing her short-lived beauty to the pictures,
That are as useless as old men, when those
Poorer in face and fortune then herself,
Walk with a hundred acres on their backs,
Fair meadows cut into green foreparts — o
It was the greatest blessing ever happened to women;
When farmer's sons agreed, and met again,
To wash their hands, and come up gentlemen;
The commonwealth has flourished ever since,
Lands that were meat by the rod, that labours spared,
Tailors ride down, and measure 'em by the yard;
Fair trees, those comely foretops of the field,
Are cut to maintain head-tires — much untold,
All thrives but chastity, she lies a cold,
Nay shall I come nearer to you, mark but this:
sp.p:
Why are there so few honest women, but because 'tis the poorer profession, that's accounted best, that's best followed, lest in trade, lest in fashion, and that's not honesty believe it, and do but note the love and dejected price of it:
Lose but a pearl, we search and cannot brook it.
But that once gone, who is so mad to look it.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Troth he says true.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: False, I defy you both:
I have endured you with an ear of fire,
Your tongues have struck hot irons on my face;
Mother, come from that poisonous woman there.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do you not see her, she's too inward then:
Slave perish in thy office: you heavens please,
Henceforth to make the mother a disease,
Which first begins with me, yet I've outgone you.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O angels clap your wings upon the skies,
And give this virgin crystal plaudities?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Peevish, coy, foolish, but return this answer,
My lord shall be most welcome, when his pleasure
Conducts him this way, I will sway mine own,
Women with women can work best alone.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Indeed I'll tell him so;
Oh more uncivil, more unnatural,
Than those base-titled creatures that look downward,
Why does not heaven turn black, or with a frown
Undo the world — why does not earth start up,
And strike the sins that tread upon't — o;
Wert not for gold and women; there would be no damnation,
Hell would look like a lord's great kitchen without fire in't;
But 'twas decreed before the world began,
That they should be the hooks to catch, at man.

div.stage: Enter Lussurioso, with Hippolito, vindicies brother.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I much applaud thy judgement, thou art well read in a fellow,
And 'tis the deepest art to study man;
I know this, which I never learned in schools,
The world's divided into knaves and fools.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Knave in your face my lord, behind your back.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: And I much thank thee, that thou hast preferred,
A fellow of discourse — well mingled,
And whose brain time hath seasoned.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: True my lord,
we shall find season once I hope; — oh villain!
To make such an unnatural slave of me; — but —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Mass here he comes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And now shall I have free leave to depart.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Your absence, leave us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Are not my thoughts true?
I must remove; but brother you may stay,
Heart, we are both made bawds a new-found way?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Now, we're an even number? A third man's dangerous,
Especially her brother, say, be free,
Have I a pleasure towards.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Ravish me in thine answer, art thou rare,
Hast thou beguiled her of salvation,
And rubbed hell o'er with honey; is she a woman?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: In all but in desire.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Then she's in nothing, — I bate in courage now.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The words I brought,
Might well have made indifferent honest, naught,
A right good woman in these days in change,
Into white money with less labour far,
Many a maid has turned to Mahomet,
With easier working; I durst undertake
Upon the pawn and forfeit of my life.
With half those words to flat a Puritans wife,
But she is close and good; — yet 'tis a doubt by this time; o the mother, the mother?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I never thought their sex had been a wonder,
Until this minute? what fruit from the mother?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Now must I blister my soul, be forsworn,
Or shame the woman that received me first,
I will be true, thou liv'st not to proclaim,
Spoke to a dying man, shame has no shame.
My lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Here's none but I my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What would thy haste utter?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Comfort.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Welcome.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The maid being dull, having no mind to travel,
Into unknown lands, what did me I straight,
but set spurs to the mother; golden spurs,
Will put her to a false gallop in a trice,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Is't possible that in this.
The mother should be damned before the daughter?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O, that's good manners my lord, the mother for her age must go foremost you know.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou'st spoke that true but where comes in this comfort.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: In a fine place my lord — the unnatural mother,
Did with her tongue so hard be set her honour,
That the poor fool was struck to silent wonder,
Yet still the maid like an unlighted taper,
Was cold and chaste, save that her mother's breath,
Did blow fire on her checks, the girl departed,
But the good ancient madam half mad, threw me
These promissing words, which I took deeply note of;
My lord shall be most welcome,

sp.speaker: Luss
sp.l: Faith I thank her,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: When his pleasure conducts him this way.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: That shall be soon ifath,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I will sway mine own,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: She does the wiser I commend her fort,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Women with women can work best alone,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: By this light and so they can, give 'em their due, men are not comparable to 'em.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: No that's true, for you shall have one woman knit more in a hour than any man can ravel again in seven and twenty year.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Now my desires are happy, I'll make 'em freemen now,
Thou art a precious fellow, faith I love thee,
Be wise and make it thy revenue, beg, leg,
What office couldst thou be ambitious for?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: Office my lord marry if I might have my wish I would have one that was never begged yet,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Nay then thou canst have none.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: Yes my lord I could pick out another office yet, nay and keep a horse and drab upon't,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Prithee good bluntness tell me.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p:
Why I would desire but this my lord, to have all the fees behind the arras; and all the farthingales that fall plump
about twelve o'clock at night upon the rushes.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.p: Thou'rt a mad apprehensive knave, dost think to make any great purchase of that.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: O 'tis an unknown thing my lord, I wonder t'has been missed so long?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Well, this night I'll visit her, and 'tis till then
A year in my desires-farewell, attend,
Trust me with thy preferment.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My loved lord;
O shall I kill him ath' wrong-side now, no!
Sword thou wast never a backbiter yet,
I'll pierce him to his face, he shall die, looking upon me,
Thy veins are swollen with lust, this shall unfill 'em,
Great men were gods, if beggars could not kill 'em,
Forgive me heaven, to call my mother wicked,
O lessen not my days upon the earth
I cannot honour her, by this I fear me
Her tongue has turned my sister into use.
I was a villain not to be forsworn:
To this our lecherous hope, the Duke's son,
For lawyers, merchants, some divines and all,
Count beneficial perjury a sin small,
It shall go hard yet, but I'll guard her honour
And keep the ports sure?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother how goes the world? I would know news of you
But I have news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: What in the name of knavery?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Knavery faith,
This vicious old duke's worthily abused
The pen of his bastard writes him cuckold!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: His bastard?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Pray believe it, he and the Duchess,
By night meet in their linen, they have been seen
By stair-foot panders!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O sin foul and deep,
Great faults are winked at when the duke's asleep ,
See, see, here comes the Spurio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Monstrous luxur?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Unbraced: two of his valiant bawds with him.
O there's a wicked whisper; hell is in his care
Stay let's observe his passage —

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: O but are you sure on't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord most sure on't, for 'twas spoken by one,
That is most inward with the Duke's son's lust:
That he intends within this hour to steal,
Unto Hippolito's sister, whose chaste life
The mother has corrupted for his use.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Sweet word, sweet occasion, faith than brother
I'll disinherit you in as short time,
As I was when I was begotten in haste:
I'll dam you at your pleasure: precious deed
After your lust, o 'twill be fine to bleed,
Come let our passing out be soft and wary.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Mark, there, there, that step, now to the Duchess,
This their second meeting, writes the Duke cuckold
With new additions, his horns newly revived:
Night! thou that lookest like funeral herald's fees
Torn down betimes ith' morning, thou hangest fitly
To grace those sins that have no grace at all,
Now 'tis full sea a-bed over the world,
There's juggling of all sides, some that were maids
E'en at sun set are now perhaps ith' toll-book,
This woman in immodest thin apparel:
Lets in her friend by water, here a dame
Cunning, nails leather-hinges to a door,
To avoid proclamation,
Now cuckolds are a quoining, apace, apace, apace, apace?
And careful sisters spin that thread ith' night,
That does maintain them and their bawds ith' day!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You flow well brother?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Puh I'm shallow vet,
Too sparing and too modest, shall I tell thee,
If every trick were told that's dealt by night
There are few here that would not blush out right.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I am of that belief too.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Who's this comes,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The Duke's son up so late, — brother fall back,
And you shall learn, some mischief, — my good lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Piato, why the man I wished for, come,
I do embrace this season for the fittest
To taste of that young lady?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Heart, and hell.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Damned villain.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I ha' no way now to cross it, but to kill him.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Come only thou and I.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: My lord my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Why dost thou start us?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I'd almost forgotten — the bastard!

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: This night, this hour — this minute, now.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What? what?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Shadows the Duchess —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Horrible word.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: And like strong poison eats,
Into the Duke your father's forehead.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: He makes horn royal.

sp.speaker: Lus:
sp.l: Most ignoble slave?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: This is the fruit of two beds.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That passage he trod warily:

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: He did!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: And hushed his villains every step he took.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: His villains? I'll confound them.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Take 'em finely, finely, now.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: The Duchess chamber-door shall not control me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Good, happy, swift, there's gunpowder ith' court,
Wild fire at midnight, in this heedless fury
He may show violence to cross himself,
I'll follow the event.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Where is that villain?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Softly my lord and you may take 'em twisted.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I care not how!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O 'twill be glorious,
To kill 'em doubled, when their heaped, be soft my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Away my spleen is not so lazy, thus and thus,
I'll shake their eyelids open, and with my sword
Shut 'em again for ever; — villain, strumpet —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You upper guard defend us.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O take me not in sleep, I have great sins, I must have days,
Nay months dear son, with penitential heaves,
To lift 'em out, and not to die unclear,
oh thou wilt kill me both in heaven and here.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I am amazed to death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay villain traitor,
Worse than the foulest epithet, now I'll gripe thee
E'en with the nerves of wrath, and throw thy head
Amongst the lawyer's guard.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble.
sp.l: How comes the quiet of your grace disturbed?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This boy that should be myself after me,
Would be myself before me, and in heat
Of that ambition bloodily rushed in
Intending to depose me in my bed?

sp.speaker: 2. Noble.
sp.l: Duty and natural-loyalty forfend.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He called his father villain; and me strumpet,
A word that I abhor to file my lips with.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: That was not so well done brother?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I am abused — I know there's no excuse can do me good.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Tis now good policy to be from sight,
His vicious purpose to our sister's honour,
Is crossed beyond our thought.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You little dreamt his father slept here.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O 'twas far beyond me.
But since it fell so; — without frightful word,
Would he had killed him, 'twould have eased our swords.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be comforted our Duchess, he shall die.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Where's this slave-pander now? out of mine eye,
Guilty of this abuse.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: You're villains, fablers,
You have knaves chins, and harlot's tongues, you lie,
And I will dam you with one meal a day.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: O good my lord!

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: 'Sblood you shall never sup.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: O I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: To let my sword — catch cold so long and miss him.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: Troth my lord — 'twas his intent to meet there.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Heart he's yonder?
Ha? what news here? is the day out ath' socket,
that it is noon at midnight; the court up,
How comes the guard so saucy with his elbows?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: The bastard here?
Nay then the truth of my intent shall out,
My lord and father hear me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bear him hence.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I can with loyalty excuse.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Excuse? to prison with the villain,
Death shall not long lag after him.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Good i'faith, then 'tis not much amiss,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Brothers, my best release lies on your tongues,
I pray persuade for me.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: It is our duties: make yourself sure of us.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: We'll sweat in pleading.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: And I may live to thank you.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: No, thy death shall thank me better.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: He's gone: I'll after him,
And know his trespass, seem to bear a part
In all his ills, but with a Puritan heart.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Now brother, let our hate and love be woven
So subtly together, that in speaking one word for his life,
We may make three for his death,
The craftiest pleader gets most gold for breath.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Set on, I'll not be far behind you brother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is't possible a son should be disobedient as far as
The sword: it is the highest he can go no farther.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: My gracious lord, take pity, —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Pity boys?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Nay weed be loath to move your grace too much,
We know the trespass is unpardonable,
Black, wicked, and unnatural,

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: In a son, o monstrous.

sp.speaker: Ambi.
sp.l: Yet my lord,
A Duke's soft hand strokes the rough head of law,
And makes it lie smooth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But my hand shall ne'er do't.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: That as you please my lord.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: We must needs confess,
Some father would have entered into hate,
So deadly pointed, that before his eyes,
He would ha' seen the execution sound,
without corrupted favour?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: But my lord,
Your grace may live the wonder of all times,
In pardoning that offence which never yet
Had face to beg a pardon.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Honey, how's this?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Forgive him good my lord, hees your own son,
And I must needs say 'twas the vildlier done.

sp.speaker: Superu.
sp.l: He's the next heir — yet this true reason gathers,
None can possess that dispossess their fathers:
Be merciful; —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Here's no step-mothers-wit,
I'll try 'em both upon their love and hate.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Be merciful — although —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You have prevailed,
My wrath like flaming wax hath spent itself,
I know 'twas but some peevish moon in him: go, let him be released.

sp.speaker: Superu.
sp.l: Sfoot how now brother?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your grace doth please to speak beside your spleen,
I would it were so happy?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why go, release him.

sp.speaker: Superu.
sp.l: O my good lord, I know the fault's too weighty,
And full of general loathing; too inhuman,
Rather by all men's voices worthy death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis true too; here then, receive this signet, doom shall pass,
Direct it to the judges, he shall die
Ere many days, make haste.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: All speed that may be,
We could have wished his burden not so sore,
We knew your grace did but delay before.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Here's envy with a poor thin cover or't,
Like scarlet hid in lawn, easily spied through,
This their ambition by the mother's side,
Is dangerous, and for safety must be purged,
I will prevent their envies, sure it was
But some mistaken fury in our son,
Which these aspiring boys would climb upon:
He shall be released suddenly.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: Good morning to your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome my lords.

sp.speaker: 2. Noble
sp.l: Our knees shall take away the office of our feet for ever,
unless your grace bestow a father's eye,
Upon the clouded fortunes of your son,
And in compassionate virtue grant him that,
Which makes e'en mean men happy; liberty

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How seriously their loves and honours woo
For that, which I am about to pray them do
Which, rise my lords, your knees sign his release,
We freely pardon him.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: We owe your grace much thanks, and he much duty.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It well becomes that judge to nod at crimes,
That dos commit greater himself and lives:
I may forgive a disobedient error,
That expect pardon for adultery
And in my old days am a youth in lust:
Many a beauty have I turned to poison
In the denial, covetous of all,
Age hot, is like a monster to be seen:
My hairs are white, and yet my sins are green.

div.head: Act. 3.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Brother, let my opinion sway you once,
I speak it for the best, to have him die:
Surest and soonest, if the signet come,
Unto the judge's hands, why then his doom,
Will be deferred till sittings and court-days:
Juries and further, — faiths are bought and sold,
Oaths in these days are but the skin of gold.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: In troth 'tis true too!

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Then let's set by the judges
And fall to the officers, 'tis but mistaking
The Duke our father's meaning, and where he named,
Ere many days, 'tis but forgetting that
And, have him die i'th morning.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Excellent,
Then am I heir — Duke in a minute.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Nay,
And he were once puff out, here is a pin.
Should quickly prick your bladder.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Blast occasion,
He being packed, we'll have some trick and wile,
To wind our younger brother out of prison,
That lies in for the rape, the ladies dead,
And people's thoughts will soon be buried.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: We may with safety do't, and live and feed,
The duchess-sons are too proud to bleed,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: We are i'faith to say true. — come let's not linger
I'll to the officers, go you before,
And set an edge upon the executioner.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Let me alone to grind him.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Meet; farewell,
I am next now, I rise just in that place,
Where thou'rt cut of, upon thy neck kind brother,
The falling of one head, lifts up another.

div.stage: Enter with the nobles, Lussurioso from prison.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: My lords? I am so much indebted to your loves,
For this, oh this delivery.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: But our duties, my lord, unto the hopes that grow in you,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: If ere I live to be myself I'll thank you,
Oh liberty thou sweet and heavenly dame;
But hell for prison is too mild a name.

div.stage: Enter Ambitioso, and Superuacuo? with officers.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Officers? here's the Duke's signet, your firm warrant,
Brings the command of present death a long with it
Unto our brother, the Duke's son; we are sorry,
That we are so unnaturally employed
In such an unkind office, fitter far
For enemies than brothers.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: But you know,
The Duke's command must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: It must and shall my lord — this morning then,
So suddenly?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I alas poor-good-soul,
He must break fast betimes, the executioner
Stands ready to put forth his cowardly valour.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: Already?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Already ifath, oh sir, destruction hies,
And that is least impudent, soonest dies,

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: Troth you say true my lord we take our leaves,
Our office shall be sound, we'll not delay,
The third part of a minute.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I herein you show.
Yourselves good men, and upright officers,
Pray let him die as private as he may,
Do him that favour, for the gaping people.
Will but trouble him at his prayers,
And make him curse, and swear, and so die black.
Will you be so far kind?

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: It shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Why we do thank you, if we live to be,
You shall have a better office,

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: Your good lordship,

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Commend us to the scaffold in our tears.

sp.speaker: 1. officer
sp.l: We'll weep and do your commendations,

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Fine fools in office!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Things fall our so fit.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: So happily, come brother ere next clock,
His head will be made serve a bigger block.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: No news lately from our brothers?
Are they unmindful of us?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: My lord a messenger came newly in and brought this from 'em,

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Nothing but paper comforts?
I looked for my delivery before this,
Had they been worth their oaths — prithee be from us.
Now what say you forsooth, speak out I pray,
Letter. Brother be of good cheer,
'Slud it begins like a whore with good cheer,
Thou shalt not be long a prisoner.
Not five and thirty year like a banqrout, I think so,
We have thought upon a device to get thee out by a trick!
By a trick, pox a your trick and it be so long a playing.
And so rest comforted, be merry and expect it suddenly!
Be merry, hang merry, draw and quarter merry, I'll be mad.
sp.p: Is't not strange that a man should lie in a whole month for a woman, well, we shall see how sudden our brothers: will be in their promise, I must expect still a trick! I shall not be long a prisoner, how now, what news?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Bad news my lord I am discharged of you.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Slave callest thou that bad news, I thank you brothers.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: My lord 'twill prove so, here come the officers,
Into whose hands I must commit you.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: Ha, officers what, why?

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: You must pardon us my lord,
Our office must be sound, here is our warrant
The signet from the Duke, you must straight suffer.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Suffer? I'll suffer you to be gone, I'll suffer you,
To come no more, what would you have me suffer?

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: My lord those words were better changed to prayers,
The times but brief with you, prepare to die.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Sure 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: 3. Officer
sp.l: It is too true my lord.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: I tell you 'tis not, for the Duke my father,
Defend me till next sitting, and I look
E'en every minute threescore times an hour,
For a release, a trick wrought by my brothers.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: A trick my lord? if you expect such comfort,
Your hopes as fruitless as a barren woman:
Your brothers were the unhappy messengers,
That brought this powerful token for your death.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: My brothers, no, no.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: 'Tis most true my lord.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: My brothers to bring a warrant for my death
How strange this shows?

sp.speaker: 3. Officer
sp.l: There's no delaying time.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Desire 'em hither, call 'em up, my brothers?
They shall deny it to your faces.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: My lord,
They're far enough by this, at least at court,
And this most strict command they left behind 'em,
When grief swum in their eyes, they showed like brothers,
Brimful of heavy sorrow: but the Duke
Must have his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.l: His pleasure?

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: These were their last words which my memory bears,
Commend us to the scaffold in our tears.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Pox dry their tears, what should I do with tears?
I hate 'em worse than any citizen's son
Can hate salt water; here came a letter now,
New-bleeding from their pens, scarce stinted yet,
Would I'd been torn in pieces when I tore it,
Look you officious whoresons words of comfort,
Not long a prisoner.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: It says true in that sir, for you must suffer presently.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: A villainous Duns, upon the letter knavish exposition,
Look you then here sir: we'll get thee out by a trick says he.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer
sp.l: That may hold too sir, for you know a trick is commonly
Four cards, which was meant by us four officers.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Worse and worse dealing.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: The hour beckons us,
The headsman waits, lift up your eyes to heaven.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: I thank you faith; good pretty-wholesome counsel,
I should look up to heaven as you said,
Whilst he behind me cozens me of my head,
I that's the trick.

sp.speaker: 3. Officer
sp.l: You delay too long my lord.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Stay good authorities bastards, since I must
Through brother's perjury die, oh let me venom
Their souls with curses.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: Come 'tis no time to curse.

sp.speaker: Junior.
sp.l: Must I bleed then, without respect of sign? well —
My fault was sweet sport, which the world approves,
I die for that which every woman loves.

div.stage: Enter Vindice with Hippolito his brother.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O sweet, delectable, rare, happy, ravishing,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why what's the matter brother?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O 'tis able, to make a man spring up, and knock his forehead
Against yond silver ceiling.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Prithee tell me,
Why may not I partake with you? you vowed once
To give me share to every tragic thought.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Byth' mass I think I did too,
Then I'll divide it to thee, — the old Duke
Thinking my outward shape, and inward heart
are cut out of one piece; (For he that prates his secrets,
His heart stands ath' out side) hires me by price:
To greet him with a lady,
In some fit place veiled from the eyes ath' court,
Some darkened blushless angle, that is guilty
Of his forefather's lusts, and great-folks riots,
To which (I easily to maintain my shape)
Consented, and did wish his impudent grace
To meet her here in this un-sunned-lodge,
Wherein 'tis night at noon, and here the rather,
Because unto the torturing of his soul,
The bastard and the Duchess have appointed
Their meeting too in this luxurious circle,
Which most afflicting sight will kill his eyes
Before we kill the rest of him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Twill i'faith, most dreadfully digested,
I see not how you could have missed me brother.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: True, but the violence of my joy forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ay, but where's that lady now?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O at that word,
I'm lost again, you cannot find me yet
I'm in a throng of happy apprehensions.
He's suited for a lady, I have taken care
For a delicious lip, a sparkling eye,
You shall be witness brother;
Be ready stand with your hat off.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Troth I wonder what lady it should be?
Yet 'tis no wonder, now I think again,
To have a lady stoop to a Duke, that stoops unto his men,
'Tis common to be common, through the world:
And there's more private common shadowing vices,
Than those who are known both by their names and princes
'Tis part of my allegiance to stand bare,
To the Duke's concubine, — and here she comes.

div.stage: Enter Vindice, with the skull of his love dressed up in tires.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Madame his grace will not be absent long.
Secret? ne'er doubt us madam? 'twill be worth
Three velvet gowns to your ladyship — known?
Few ladies respect that? disgrace, a poor thin shell,
'Tis the best grace you have to do it well,
I'll save your hand that labour, I'll unmask you?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why brother, brother.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Art thou beguiled now? tut, a lady can,
At such all hid, beguile a wiser man,
Have I not fitted the old surfeiter
With a quaint piece of beauty, age and bare bone
Are ere allied in action; here's an eye,
Able to tempt a great-man — to serve God,
A pretty hanging lip, that has for got now to dissemble
Methinks this mouth should make a swearer tremble.
A drunkard clasp his teeth, and not undo 'em,
To suffer wet damnation to run through 'em.
Here's a cheek keeps her colour let the wind go whistle,
Spout rain, we fear thee not, be hot or cold
All's one with us; and is not he absurd,
Whose fortunes are upon their faces set,
That fear no other god but wind and wet.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother you've spoken that right,
Is this the form that living shone so bright?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The very same,
And now methinks I could e'en chide myself,
For doting on her beauty, though her death
Shall be revenged after no common action;
Does the silkworm expend her yellow labours
For thee? for thee dos she undo herself?
Are lordships sold to maintain ladyships
For the poor benefit of a bewitching minute?
Why dos yond fellow falsify highways
And put his life between the judge's lips,
To refine such a thing keeps horse and men
To beat their valours for her?
Surely we're all mad people, and they
Whom we think are, are not, we mistake those,
'Tis we are mad in sense, they but in clothes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith and in clothes too we, give us our due.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Dos every proud and self-affecting dame
camphire her face for this? and grieve her maker
In sinful baths of milk, — when many an infant starves,
For her superfluous outside, all for this?
Who now bids twenty pound a night, prepares
Music, perfumes, and sweetmeats, all are hushed,
Thou mayst lie chaste now! it were fine methinks :
To have thee seen at revels, forgetful feasts,
And unclean brothels; sure 'twould fright the sinner
And make him a good coward, put a reveller,
Out off his antic amble
And cloy an epicure with empty dishes?
Here might a scornful and ambitious woman,
Look through and through herself, — see ladies, with false forms,
You deceive men, but cannot deceive worms.
Now to my tragic business, look you brother,
I have not fashioned this only — for show
And useless property, no, it shall bear a part
E'en in it own revenge. This very skull,
Whose mistress the Duke poisoned, with this drug
The mortal curse of the earth; shall be revenged
In the like strain, and kiss his lips to death,
As much as the dumb thing can, he shall feel:
What fails in poison, we'll supply in steel.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother I do applaud thy constant vengeance,
The quaintness of thy malice above thought.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: So 'tis laid on: now come and welcome Duke,
I have her for thee, I protest it brother:
Methinks she makes almost as fair a sign
As some old gentlewoman in a periwig?
Hide thy face now for shame, thou hadst need have a mask now
'Tis vain when beauty flows, but when it fleets
This would become graves better than the streets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You have my voice in that; hark, the duke's come.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Peace, let's observe what company he brings,
And how he dos absent 'em, for you know
He'll wish all private, — brother fall you back a little,
With the bony lady.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That I will.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: So, so, — now 9. years vengeance crowd into a minute!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You shall have leave to leave us, with this charge,
Upon your lives, if we be missed by'th Duchess
Or any of the nobles, to give out,
We're privately rid forth.

sp.speaker: Vind
sp.l: O happiness!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: With some few honourable gentlemen you may say,
You may name those that are away from court.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Your will and pleasure shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Priuatly rid forth,
He strives to make sure work on't — your good grace?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Piato, well done hast brought her, what lady is't?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: Faith my lord a country lady, a little bashful at first as most of them are, but after the first kiss my lord the worst is past with them, your grace knows now what you have to do; sha's somewhat a grave look with her — but —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I love that best, conduct her.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Have at all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: In gravest looks the greatest faults seem less
Give me that sin that's robbed in holiness.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Back with the torch; brother raise the perfumes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How sweet can a Duke breath? age has no fault,
Pleasure should meet in a perfumed mist,
Lady sweetly encountered, I came from court I must be bold with you, o, what's this, o!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Royal villain, white devil;

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Brother — place the torch here, that his affrighted eyeballs
May start into those hollows, Duke; dost know
Yond dreadful vizard, view it well, 'tis the skull
Of Gloriana, whom thou poisonedst last.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O, 'thas poisoned me.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Didst not know that till now?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What are you two?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Villains all three? — the very ragged bone,
Has been sufficiently revenged.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O Hippolito? call treason.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yes my good lord, treason, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then I'm betrayed.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Alas poor lecher in the hands of knaves,
A slavish Duke is baser than his slaves.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My teeth are eaten out.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Hadst any lest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I think but few.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Then those that did eat are eaten.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O my tongue.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Your tongue? 'twill teach you to kiss closer,
Not like a flobbering Dutchman, you have eyes still:
Look monster, what a lady hast thou made me,
My once betrothed wife.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is it thou villain, nay then —

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Tis I, 'tis vindici, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And let this comfort thee: our lord and father
Fell sick upon the infection of thy frowns,
And died in sadness; be that thy hope of life.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: He had his tongue, yet grief made him die speechless.
Puh, 'tis but early yet, now I'll begin
To stick thy soul with ulcers, I will make
Thy spirit grievous sore, it shall not rest,
But like some pestilent man toss in thy breast - (Mark me Duke)
Thou'rt a renowned, high, and mighty cuckold.

sp.speaker: Duke.
