sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Thy bastard, thy bastard rides a hunting in thy brow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Millions of deaths.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay to afflict thee more,
Here in this lodge they meet for damned clips,
Those eyes shall see the incest of their lips.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is there a hell besides this, villains?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Villain?
Nay heaven is just, scorns are the hires of scorns,
I ne'er knew yet adulterer without horns.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Once ere they die 'tis quit.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Hark the music,
Their banquet is prepared, they're coming —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, kill me not with that sight.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Thou shalt not lose that sight for all thy dukedom.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Traitors, murderers?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What? is not thy tongue eaten out yet?
Then we'll invent a silence? brother stifle the torch,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Treason, murder?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay faith, we'll have you hushed now with thy dagger
Nail down his tongue, and mine shall keep possession
About his heart, if he but gasp he dies,
we dread not death to quittance injuries; — brother,
If he but wink, not brooking the foul object,
Let our two other hands tear up his lids,
And make his eyes like comets shine through blood,
When the bad bleeds, then is the tragedy good,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Whist, brother, music's at our ear, they come.

div.stage: Enter the bastard meeting the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Had not that kiss a taste of sin 'twere sweet.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why there's no pleasure sweet but it is sinful.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: True, such a bitter sweetness fate hath given,
Best side to us, is the worst side to heaven.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Push, come: 'tis the old Duke thy doubtful father,
The thought of him rubs heaven in thy way,
But I protest by yonder waxen fire,
Forget him, or I'll poison him.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Madam, you urge a thought which ne'er had life,
So deadly do I loathe him for my birth,
That if he took me hasped within his bed,
I would add murder to adultery,
And with my sword give up his years to death.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why now thou'rt sociable, let's in and feast,
Loud'st music sound: pleasure is banquet's guest.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I cannot brook —

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: The brook is turned to blood.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thanks to loud music.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Twas our friend indeed,
'Tis state in music for a Duke to bleed:
The dukedom wants a head, though yet unknown,
As fast as they peep up, let's cut 'em down.

div.stage: Enter the Duchess two sons, Ambitioso and Supervacuo.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Was not his execution rarely plotted?
We are the Duke's sons now.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: I you may thank my policy for that.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your policy, for what?

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Why wast not my invention brother,
To slip the judges, and in lesser compass,
Did not I draw the model of his death,
Advising you to sudden officers,
And e'en extemporal execution.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Heart, 'twas a thing I thought on too.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: You thought on't too, 'sfoot slander not your thoughts
With glorious untruth, I know 'twas from you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir I say, 'twas in my head.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Ay, like your brains then,
Ne'er to come out as long as you lived.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: You'd have the honour on't forsooth, that your wit
Lead him to the scaffold,

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Since it is my due,
I'll published, but I'll have't in spite of you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Methinks you're much too bold, you should a little
Remember us brother, next to be honest Duke.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Ay, it shall be as easy for you to be Duke,
As to be honest, and that's never i'faith.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Well, cold he is by this time, and because
We're both ambitious, be it our amity,
And let the glory be shared equally.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: I am content to that.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: This night out younger brother shall out of prison,
I have a trick.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: A trick, prithee what is't?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We'll get him out by a wile.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Prithee what wile?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No sir, you shall not know it, till't be done,
For then you'd swear 'twere yours.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: How now, what's he?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: One of the officers.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Desired news.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How now my friend?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: My lords, under your pardon, I am allotted
To that desertless office, to present you
With the yet bleeding head.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Ha, ha, excellent.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: All's sure our own: brother, canst weep thinkst thou?
'Twould grace our flattery much; think of some dame,
'Twill teach thee to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: I have thought, — now for yourself.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Our sorrows are so fluent,
Our eyes o'erflow our tongues, words spoke in tears,
Are like the murmurs of the waters, the sound
Is loudly heard, but cannot be distinguished.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: How died he pray?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: O full of rage and spleen.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: He died most valiantly then, we're glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: We could not woe him once to pray.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: He showed himself a gentleman in that: give him his due.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: But in the steed of prayer, he drew forth oaths.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Then did he pray dear heart,
Although you understood him not.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: My lords,
E'en at his last, with pardon be it spoke,
He cursed you both.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: He cursed us? lass good soul.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: It was not in our powers, but the Duke's pleasure,
Finely dissembled a both-sides, sweet fate,
Oh happy opportunity.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Now my lords.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Oh! —

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Why do you shun me brothers?
You may come nearer now;
The savour of the prison has forsook me,
I thank such kind lords as yourselves, I'm free.

sp.speaker: Amb
sp.l: Alive!

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: In health!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Released?
We were both e'en amazed with joy to see it,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I am much to thank you.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Faith we spared no tongue, unto my lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I know your delivery brother
Had not been half so sudden but for us.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: O how we pleaded.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Most deserving brothers,
In my best studies I will think of it?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: O death and vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Hell and torments.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Slave camest thou to delude us.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Delude you my lords?

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: I villain, where's this head now?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Why here my lord,
Just after his delivery, you both came
With warrant from the Duke to behead your brother.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Ay, our brother, the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: The Duke's son my lord, had his release before you came.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Whose head's that then?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: His whom you left command for, your own brothers?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Our brothers? o furies —

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Plagues.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Confusions.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Darkness.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Devils.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Fell it out so accursedly?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: So damnedly.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Villain I'll brain thee with it,

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: O my good lord!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: The devil overtake thee?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: O fatal.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: O prodigious to our bloods.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Did we dissemble?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Did we make our tears women for thee?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Laugh and rejoice for thee.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Bring warrant for thy death.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Mock off thy head

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: You had a trick, you had a wile forsooth.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: A murrain meet 'em, there's none of these wiles that ever come to good: I see now, there is nothing sure in mortality, but mortality, well, no more words shalt be revenged i'faith.
sp.l: Come, throw off clouds now brother, think of vengeance,
And deeper settled hate, sirrah sit fast,
We'll pull down all, but thou shalt down at last.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 1.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My lord:
Has your good lordship ought to command me in?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I prithee leave us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How's this? come and leave us?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your honour — I stand ready for any duteous employment.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Heart, what mak'st thou here?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A pretty lordly humour:
He bids me to be present, to depart; something has stung his honour?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Be nearer, draw nearer:
You're not so good methinks , I'm angry with you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: With me my lord? I'm angry with myself fort.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: You did prefer a goodly fellow to me,
'Twas wittily elected, 'twas, I thought
Had been a villain, and he proves a knave?
To me a knave.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I chose him for the best my lord,
'Tis much my sorrow, if neglect in him, breed discontent in you.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Neglect, 'twas will: judge of it,
Firmly to tell of an incredible act,
Not to be thought, less to be spoken of,
Twixt my stepmother and the bastard, o,
Incestuous sweets between 'em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fie my lord.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I in kind loyalty to my father's forehead,
Made this a desperate arm, and in that fury,
Committed treason on the lawful bed,
And with my sword e'en razed my father's bosom,
For which I was within a stroke of death.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alack, I'm sorry; 'sfoot just upon the stroke,
Jars in my brother, 'twill be villainous music.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Away prithee forsake us, hereafter we'll not know thee.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Not know me my lord, your lordship cannot choose.

sp.speaker: Lus
sp.l: Begun I say, thou art a false knave.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Why the easier to be known, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Push, I shall prove too bitter with a word,
Make thee a perpetual prisoner,
And say this iron-age upon thee,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Mum, for there's a doom would make a woman dumb,
Missing the bastard next him, the wind's comes about,
Now 'tis my brother's turn to stay mine to go out.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Has greatly moved me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Much to blame i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: But I'll recover, to his ruin: 'twas told me lately,
I know not whether falsely, that you'd a brother,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Who I, yes my good lord, I have a brother

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: How chance the court ne'er saw him? of what nature?
How does he apply his hours?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith to curse fates,
Who, as he thinks, ordained him to be poor,
Keeps at home full of want and discontent.

sp.speaker: Lus
sp.l: There's hope in him, for discontent and want
Is the best clay to mould, a villain off;
Hippolito, wish him repair to us,
If there be ought in him to please our blood,
For thy sake we'll advance him, and build fair
His meanest fortunes: for it is in us
To rear up towers from cottages.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is so my lord, he will attend your honour,
But he's a man, in whom much melancholy dwells.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Why the better: bring him to court.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: With willingness and speed,
Whom he cast off e'en now, must now succeed,
Brother disguise must off,
In thine own shape now, I'll prefer thee to him:
How strangely does himself work to undo him.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: This fellow will come fitly, he shall kill,
That other slave, that did abuse my spleen,
And made it swell to treason, I have put
Much of my heart into him, he must die.
He that knows great men's secrets and proves slight,
That man ne'er lives to see his beard turn white:
I he shall speed him: I'll employ thee brother,
Slaves are but nails, to drive out one another?
He being of black condition, suitable
To want and ill content, hope of preferment
Will grind him to an edge — the nobles enter.
Good days unto your honour.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: My kind lords, I do return the like,
Saw you my lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: My lord and father, is he from court?
He's sure from court,
But where, which way, his pleasure took we know not,
Nor can we hear on't.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Here come those should tell,
Saw you my lord and father?
Not since two hours before noon my lord,
And then he privately rid forth.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O he's rod forth.
'Twas wondrous privately,
There's none ith' court had any knowledge on't.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: His grace is old, and sudden, 'tis no treason
To say, the Duke my father has a humour,
Or such a toy about him; what in us
Would appear light, in him seems virtuous.
'Tis oracle my lord.

div.stage: Enter Vindice and Hippolito, vind. out of his disguise.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: So, so, all's as it should be, you're yourself.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: How that great-villain puts me to my shifts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He that did lately, in disguise reject thee;
Shall now thou art thyself, as much respect thee.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Twill be the quainter fallacy; but brother,
Sfoot what use will he put me to now thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay you must pardon me in that, I know not:
Has some employment for you: but what 'tis
He and his secretary the devil knows best.

sp.speaker: Vind,
sp.l: Well I must suit my tongue to his desires,
What colour soe'er they be; hoping at last
To pile up all my wishes on his breast,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith brother he himself shows the way.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Now the Duke is dead, the realm is clad in clay:
His death being not yet known, under his name
The people still are governed; well, thou his son
Art not long-lived, thou shalt not joy his death:
To kill thee then, I should most honour thee;
For 'twould stand firm in every man's belief,
Thou'st a kind child, and only died'st with grief.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You fetch about well, but let's talk in present,
How will you appear in fashion different,
As well as in apparel, to make all things possible:
If you be but once tripped, we fall for ever.
It is not the least policy to be doubtful,
You must change tongue: — familiar was your first.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Why I'll bear me in some strain of melancholy,
And string myself with heavy — sounding wire,
Like such an instrument, that speaks merry things sadly.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Then 'tis as I meant,
I gave you out at first in discontent.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I'll turn myself, and then —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sfoot here he comes: hast thought upon't.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Salute him, fear not me.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your lordship.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What's he yonder?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis vindici, my discontented brother,
Whom, 'cording to your will I've brought to court.

sp.speaker: Luss,
sp.l: Is that thy brother? beshrew me, a good presence,
I wonder has been from the court so long?
Come nearer.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother, lord Lussurioso the Duke son.

div.stage: Snatches of his hat and makes legs to him.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Be more near to us, welcome, nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: How don you? god you god den.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: We thank thee?
How strangely such a course-homely salute,
Shows in the palace, where we greet in fire:
Nimble and desperate tongues, should we name,
God in a salutation, 'twould ne'er be stood on't, - heaven!
Tell me, what has made thee so melancholy.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Why, going to law.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Why will that make a man melancholy?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: Yes, to look long upon ink and black buckram — I went me to law in anno quadragesimo secundo, and I waded out of it, in anno sextagesimo tertio.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What, three and twenty years in law?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: I have known those that have been five and fifty and all about pullen and pigs.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: May it be possible such men should breathe,
To vex the terms so much.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Tis food to some my lord. There are old men at the present, that are so poisoned with the affectation of law-words, (Having had many suits canvased,) that their common talk is nothing but Barbery latin: they cannot so much as pray, but in law, that their sins may be removed, with a writ of error, and their souls fetched up to heaven, with a sasarara.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It seems most strange to me,
Yet all the world meets round in the same bent:
Where the hearts set, there goes the tongue's consent,
How dost apply thy studies fellow?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p:
Study why to think how a great rich man lies a dying, and a poor cobbler tolls the bell for him? how he cannot depart the world, and see the great chest-stand before him, when he lies speechless, how he will point you readily to all the boxes, and when he is passed all memory, as the gossips guess, then thinks he of forfeitures and obligations, nay when to all men's hearings he whirls and rattles in the throat he's busy threatening his poor tenants? and this would last me now some seven years thinking or thereabouts ? but, I have a
conceit a coming in picture upon this, I draw it myself, which i'faith la I'll present to your honour, you shall not choose but like it for your lordship shall give me nothing for it,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Nay you mistake me then,
For I am published bountiful enough,
Let's taste of your conceit.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: In picture my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: I in picture,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Marry this it is — a usuring father to be boiling in hell, and his son and heir with a whore dancing over him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Has pared him to the quick.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: The conceit's pretty i'faith,
But take't upon my life 'twill ne'er be liked.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: No, why I'm sure the whore will be liked well enough.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I if she were out ath' picture heed like her then himself.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And as for the son and heir, he shall be an eyesore to no young revellers, for he shall be drawn in cloth of gold breeches.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: And thou hast put my meaning in the pock,
And canst not draw that out, my thought was this, ets
To see the picture of a usuring father
Boiling in hell, our richmen would ne'er like it,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O true I cry you heart'ly mercy I know the reason, for some of 'em had rather be damned indeed, than damned in colours.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: A perilous melancholy, has wit enough,
To murder any man, and I'll give him means,
I think thou art ill moneyed;

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Money, ho, ho,
'Thas been my want so long, 'tis now my scoff.
I've e'en forgotten what colour silvers off,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: It hits as I could wish,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I get good clothes,
Of those that dread my humour, and for table-room,
I feed on those that cannot be rid of me,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Somewhat to set thee up withal,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O mine eyes,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: How now man.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Almost struck blind,
This bright unusual shine, to me seems proud,
I dare not look till the sun be in a cloud,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I think I shall affect his melancholy,
how are they now.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The better for your ask.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: You shall be better yet if you but fasten,
Truly on my intent, now you're both present
I will unbrace such a close private villain,
Unto your vengeful swords, the like never heard of,
Who hath disgraced you much and injured us,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Disgraced us my lord?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I Hippolito.
I kept it here till now that both your angers,
Might meet him at once,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I'm covetous,
To know the villain,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: You know him that slave Pandar,
Piato whom we threatened last
With irons in perpetual prisonment;

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: All this is I.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is't he my lord?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I'll tell you, you first preferred him to me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Did you brother.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I did indeed?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: And the ungrateful villain,
To quit that kindness, strongly wrought with me,
Being as you see a likely man for pleasure,
With jewels to corrupt your virgin sister.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O villain,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: He shall surely die that did it.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I far from thinking any virgin harm.
Especially knowing her to be as chaste
As that part which scarce suffers to be touched,
Th' eye would not endure him,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Would you not my lord,
'Twas wondrous honourably done,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: But with some five frowns kept him out,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Out slave.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: What did me he but in revenge of that,
Went of his own free will to make infirm,
Your sister's honour, whom I honour with my soul,
For chaste respect, and not prevailing there,
(As 'twas but desperate folly to attempt it,)
In mere spleen, by the way, way lays your mother,
Whose honour being a coward as it seems.
Yielded by little force.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Coward indeed.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: He proud of their advantage, (As he thought)
Brought me these news for happy, but I, heaven forgive me for't.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: What did your honour.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: In rage pushed him from me.
Trampled beneath his throat, spurned him, and bruised:
Indeed I was too cruel to say troth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Most nobly managed.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Has not heaven an ear? Is all the lightning wasted?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: If I now were so impatient in a modest cause,
What should you be?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Full mad, he shall not live
To see the moon change.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: He's about the palace,
Hippolito entice him this way, that thy brother
May take full mark of him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Heart? — that shall not need my lord,
I can direct him so far.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Yet for my hate's sake,
Go, wind him this way? I'll see him bleed myself.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What now brother?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay e'en what you will — you're put to't brother?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: An impossible task, I'll swear,
To bring him hither, that's already here.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Thy name, I have forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Vindice my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: 'Tis a good name that.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Ay, a revenger.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: It dos betoken courage, thou shouldst be valiant,
And kill thine enemies.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That's my hope my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: This slave is one.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I'll doom him.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Then I'll praise thee?
Do thou observe me best, and I'll best raise thee.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Indeed, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Now Hippolito, where's the slave Pandar?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your good lordship,
Would have a loathsome sight of him, much offensive?
He's not in case now to be seen my lord,
The worst of all the deadly sins is in him:
That beggarly damnation, drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Then he's a double-slave.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Twas well conveyed, upon a sudden wit.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: What, are you both,
Firmly resolved, I'll see him dead myself.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Or else, let not us live.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: You may direct your brother to take note of him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Rise but in this, and you shall never fall.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Your honour's vassals.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: This was wisely carried,
Deep policy in us, makes fools of such:
Then must a slave die, when he knows too much.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O thou almighty patience, 'tis my wonder,
That such a fellow, impudent and wicked,
Should not be cloven as he stood:
Or with a secret wind burst open!
Is there no thunder left, or is't kept up
In stock for heavier vengeance, there it goes!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother we lose ourselves?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: But I have found it,
'Twill hold, 'tis sure, thanks, thanks to any spirit,
That mingled it amongst my inventions.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: 'Tis sound, and good, thou shalt partake it,
I'm hired to kill myself.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Prithee mark it,
And the old Duke being dead, but not conveyed,
For he's already missed too, and you know:
Murder will peep out of the closest husk.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Most true?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: What say you then to this device,
If we dressed up the body of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: In that disguise of yours.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: You're quick, y' have reached it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I like it wondrously.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: And being in drink, as you have published him,
To lean him on his elbow, as if sleep had caught him:
Which claims most interest in such sluggy men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Good yet, but here's a doubt,
methought by'th Duke's son to kill that pandar,
Shall when he is known be thought to kill the Duke.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Neither, oh thanks, it is substantial
For that disguise being on him, which I wore,
sp.p: It will be thought I, which he calls the pandar, did kill the Duke, and fled away in his apparel, leaving him so disguised, to avoid swift pursuit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Firmer, and firmer.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay doubt not 'tis in grain, I warrant it hold colour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Let's about it.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: But by the way too, now I think on't, brother,
Let's conjure that base devil out of our mother.

div.stage: Enter the Duchess arm in arm with the bastard: he seemeth lasciviously to her, after them, enter Superuacuo, running with a rapier, his brother stops him.

sp.speaker: Spuri.
sp.l: Madam, unlock yourself, should it be seen,
Your arm would be suspected.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who it's that dares suspect, or this, or these?
May not we deal our favours where we please?

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: I'm confident, you may.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: 'Sfoot brother hold.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Wilt let the bastard shame us?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Hold, hold, brother? there's fitter time than now.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Now when I see it.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: 'Tis too much seen already.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Seen and known,
The nobler she's, the baser is she grown.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: If she were bent lasciviously, the fault
Of mighty women, that sleep soft, — oh death,
Must she needs choose such an unequal sinner:
To make all worse.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: A bastard, the Duke's bastard, shame heaped on shame.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: O our disgrace.
Most women have small waste the world throughout,
But there desires are thousand miles about.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Come stay not here, let's after, and prevent,
Or else the I'll sin faster than we'll repent.

div.stage: Enter Vindice and Hippolito, bringing out there mother one by one shoulder, and the other by the other, with daggers in their hands.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O thou? for whom no name is bad enough.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: What means my sons what will you murder me?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Wicked unnatural parents.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fiend of women.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Ohlare sons turned monsters? help.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: In vain.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Are you so barbarous to set iron nipples
Upon the breast that gave you suck.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That breast,
Is turned to quarled poison.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Cut not your days for't, am not I your mother?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Thou dost usurp that title now by fraud
For in that shell of mother breeds a bawd.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: A bawd? O name far loathsomer than hell.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It should be so knewest thou thy office well.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: I hate it.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Ah is't possible, thou only, you powers on high,
That women should dissemble when they die.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Dissemble.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Did not the Duke's son direct
A fellow, of the world's condition, hither,
That did corrupt all that was good in thee:
Made thee uncivilly forget thyself,
And work our sister to his lust.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Who I,
That had been monstrous? I defy that man:
For any such intent, none lives so pure,
But shall be soiled with slander, — good son believe it not,

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O I'm in doubt,
Whether I'm myself, or no,
Stay, let me look again upon this face.
Who shall be saved when mothers have no grace.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Twould make one half despair.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I was the man,
Defy me, now? let's see, do't modestly.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O hell unto my soul.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: In that disguise, I sent from the Duke's son,
Tried you, and found you base mettle,
as any villain might have done.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: One, no tongue but yours could have bewitched me so.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O nimble in damnation, quick in tune,
There is no devil could strike fire so soon:
I am confuted in a word.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O sons, forgive me, to myself I'll prove more true,
You that should honour me, I kneel to you.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: A mother to give aim to her own daughter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: True brother, how far beyond nature 'tis,
Though many mother's do't.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay and you draw tears once, go you to bed,
Wet will make iron blush and change to red:
Brother it rains, 'twill spoil your dagger, house it.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I'faith 'tis a sweet shower, it dos much good,
The fruitful grounds, and meadows of her soul,
Has been long dry: power down thou blessed dew,
Rise mother, troth this shower has made you higher.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O you heavens? take this infectious spot out of my soul,
I'll rinse it in seven waters of mine eyes?
Make my tears salt enough to taste of grace,
To weep, is to our sex: naturally given:
But to weep truly that's a gift from heaven?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Nay I'll kiss you now: kiss her brother?
Let's marry her to our souls, wherein's no lust,
And honourably love her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Let it be.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: For honest women are so filled and rare,
'Tis good to cherish those poor few that are.
O you of easy wax, do but imagine
Now the disease has left you, how leprously
That office would have clinged unto your forehead,
All mothers that had any graceful hue,
Would have worn masks to hide their face at you:
It would have grown to this, at your foul name;
Green-colored maids would have turned red with shame?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And then our sister full of hire, and baseness.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: There had been boiling led again,
The Duke's sons great concubine:
A drab of state, a cloth a silver slut,
to have her train born up, and her soul trail i'th dirt; great.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: To be miserably great, rich to be eternally wretched.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O common madness:
Ask but the thriuingst harlot in cold blood,
She give the world to make her honour good,
Perhaps you'll say but only to'th Duke's son,
In private; why, she first begins with one,
Who afterwards to thousand proves a whore:

l.quote: Break ice in one place, it will crack in more.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Most certainly applied?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O brother, you forget our business.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: And well remembered, joy's a subtle elf,
I think man's happiest, when he forgets himself:
Farewell once dried, now holy-watered mead,
Our hearts wear feathers, that before wore lead.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: I'll give you this, that one I never knew
Plead better, for, and 'gainst the devil, than you.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: You make me proud on't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Commend us in all virtue to our sister.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: I for the love of heaven, to that true maid.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: With my best words.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Why that was motherly said.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: I wonder now what fury did transport me?
I feel good thoughts begin to settle in me.
O with what forehead can I look on her?
Whose honour I've so impiously beset,
And here she comes,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now mother, you have wrought with me so strongly,
That what for my advancement, as to calm
The trouble of your tongue: I am content.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Content, to what?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: To do as you have wished me,
To prostitute my breast to the Duke's son:
And put myself to common usury.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: I hope you will not so.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hope you I will not?
That's not the hope you look to be saved in.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Truth but it is.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do not deceive yourself,
I am, as you e'en out of marble wrought,
What would you now, are ye not pleased yet with me,
You shall not wish me to be more lascivious
Than I intend to be.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Strike not me cold,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How often have you charged me on your blessing
To be a cursed woman — when you knew,
Your blessing had no force to make me lewd,
You laid your curse upon me, that did more,
The mother's curse is heavy, where that fights,
Sons set in storm, and daughters lose their lights?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Good child, dear maid, if there be any spark
Of heavenly intellectual fire within thee, o let my breath,
Revive it to a flame:
Put not all out, with woman's wilful follies,
I am recovered of that foul disease
That haunts too many mothers, kind forgive me,
Make me not sick in health? — if then
My words prevailed when they were wickedness,
How much more now when they are just and good?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I wonder what you mean, are not you she
For whose infect persuasions I could scarce
Kneel out my prayers, and had much ado
In three hours reading, to untwist so much
Of the black serpent, as you wound about me.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: 'Tis unfruitful, held tedious to repeat what's past,
I'm now your present mother.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Push, now 'tis too late,

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Bethink again, thou knowest not what thou sayst.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No, deny advancement, treasure, the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O see, I spoke those words, and now they poison me:
What will the deed do then?
Advancement, true: as high as shame can pitch,
For treasure; who ere knew a harlot rich?
Or could build by the purchase of her sin,
An hospital to keep their bastards in: the Duke's son,
O when women are young courtiers, they are sure to be old beggars,
To know the miseries most harlots taste,
Thou'dst wish thyself unborn, when thou art unchaste.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O mother let me twine about your neck,
and kiss you till my soul melt on your lips,
I did but this to try you.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O speak truth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed I did not, for no tongue has force to alter me from honest
If maidens would, men's words could have no power,
A virgin honour is a crystal tower.
Which being weak is guarded with good spirits,
Until she basely yields no ill inherits.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: O happy child! faith and thy birth hath saved me,
Amongst thousand daughters happiest of all others,
Buy thou a glass for maids and I for mothers.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: So, so, he leans well, take heed you wake him not brother

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I warrant you my life for yours.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That's a good lay, for I must kill myself?
Brother that's I: that sits for me: do you mark it,
sp.p: And I must stand ready here to make away myself yonder — I must sit to be killed, and stand to kill myself, I could vary it not so little as thrice over again, 'thas some eight returns like Michaelmas term.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That's enough a conscience.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: But sirrah dos the Duke's son come single?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No, there's the hell on't, his faith's too feeble to go alone? he brings flesh-flies after him, that will buzz against supper time, and hum for his coming out.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: Ah the fly-flop of vengeance beat 'em to pieces? here was the sweetest occasion, the fittest hour, to have made my revenge familiar with him, show him the body of the Duke his father, and how quaintly he died like a politician in hugger-mugger, made no man acquainted with it, and in catastrophe slain him over his father's breast, and o I'm mad to lose such a sweet opportunity.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay push, prithee be content! there's no remedy present, may not hereafter times open in as fair faces as this.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: They may if they can paint so well?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Come, now to avoid all suspicion, let's forsake this room, and be going to meet the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Content, I'm for any weather? heart step close, here he comes?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My honoured lord?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O me; you both present.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: E'en newly my lord, just as your lordship entered now? about this place we had notice given he should be, but in some

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Came your honour private?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Private enough for this: only a few
Attend my coming out.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Death rotten those few.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Stay yonder's the slave.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Mass there's the slave indeed my lord;
'Tis a good child, he calls his father slave.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Ay, that's the villain, the damned villain: softly,
Tread easy.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Puh, I warrant you my lord, we'll stifle in our breathes.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: That will do well:
Base rogue, thou sleepest thy last, 'tis policy,
To have him killed in's sleep, for if he waked
He would betray all to them.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: But my lord.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Ha, what sayst?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Shall we kill him now he's drunk?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I best of all.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Why then he will ne'er live to be sober?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: No matter, let him reel to hell.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: But being so full of liquor, I fear he will put out all the fire,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Thou art a mad breast.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And leave none to warm your lordship's golls withal; for he that dies drunk, falls into hell fire like a bucket a water, qush qush.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Come be ready, take your swords, think of your wrongs
This slave has injured you.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Troth so he has, and he has paid well fort.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Meet with him now.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You'll bear us out my lord?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Puh, am I a lord for nothing think you, quickly, now.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Sa, sa, sa: thump, there he lies.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Nimbly done, ha? o, villains, murderers,
'Tis the old Duke my father.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: That's a jest.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: What stiff and cold already?
O pardon me to call you from your names:
'Tis none of your deed, — that villain Piato
Whom you thought now to kill, has murdered him,
And left him thus disguised.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And no unlikely.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O rascal was he not ashamed,
To put the Duke into a greasy doublet.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: He has been cold and stiff who knows, how long?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Marry that do I.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: No words I pray, off any thing intended:

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I would same have your lordship think that we have small reason to prate.

sp.speaker: Lus
sp.l: Faith thou sayst true? I'll forthwith send to court,
For all the nobles, bastard, Duchess, all?
How here by miracle we found him dead,
And in his raiment that foul villain fled.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.p: That will be the best way my lord, to clear us all: let's cast about to be clear.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Ho, Nencio, Sordido, and the rest.
My lord.
My lord.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Be witnesses of a strange spectacle:
Choosing for private conference that sad room
We found the Duke my father gealed in blood.
My lord the Duke — run hie thee Nencio,
Startle the court by signifying so much.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Thus much by wit a deep revenger can:
When murders known to be the clearest man
We're furthest off, and with as bold an eye,
Survey his body as the standers by.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: My royal father, too basely let blood,
By a malevolent slave.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Hark? he calls thee slave again.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Has lost, he may.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O sight, look hither, see, his lips are gnawn with poison.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How — his lips by'th mass they be.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O villain — oh rogue — oh slave — oh rascal:

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O good deceit, he quits him with like terms.
Where.
Which way.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Over what roof hangs this prodigious comet,
In deadly fire.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Behold, behold my lords the Duke my fathers murdered by a vassal, that owes this habit, and here left disguised.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My lord and husband.
Reverend majesty.
I have seen these clothes, often attending on him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That nobleman, has been ith' country, for he dos not lie?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Learn of our mother let's dissemble to,
I am glad he's vanished; so I hope are you?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I you may take my word fort.

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.l: Old dad, dead?
Ay, one of his cast sins will send the fates
Most hearty commendations by his own son,
I'll tug in the new stream, till strength be done.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Where be those two, that did affirm to us?
My lord the Duke was privately rid forth?
O pardon us my lords, he gave that charge
Upon our lives if he were missed at court,
To answer so; he road not anywhere ,
We left him private with that fellow here?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Confirmed.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O heavens, that false charge was his death,
Impudent beggars, durst you to our face,
Maintain such a false answer? bear him straight to execution.
My lord?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Urge me no more.
In this the excuse, may be called half the murder?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: You've sentenced well.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Away see it be done.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Could you not stick: see what confession doth?
Who would not lie when men are hanged for truth?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother how happy is our vengeance.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why it hits, passed the apprehension of indifferent wits.

sp.speaker: Luss,
sp.l: My lord let post-horse be sent,
Into all places to entrap the villain,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Post-horse ha ha.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: My lord, we're something bold to know our duty?
Your fathers accidentally departed,
The titles that were due to him, meet you.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Meet me? I'm not at leisure my good lord,
I've many griefs to dispatch out ath' way:
Welcome sweet titles, — talk to me my lords,
Of sepulchers, and mighty emperor's bones,
That's thought for me.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: So, one may see by this,
How foreign markets go:
Courtiers have feet ath' nines, and tongues ath' twelves,
they flatter Dukes and Dukes flatter themselves.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: My lord it is your shine must comfort us.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Alas I shine in tears like the sun in April.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: Your now my lords grace?

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: My lords grace? I perceive you'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: 'Tis but your own.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Then heavens give me grace to be so?

sp.speaker: Vind
sp.l: He prays well for himself.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: Madam all sorrows,
Must run their circles into joys, no doubt but time,
Will make the murderer bring forth himself.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: He were an ass then i'faith?

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: In the mean season,
Let us bethink the latest-funerall honours:
Endue to the Duke's cold body, — and withal,
Calling to memory our new happiness,
Spread in his royal son, — lords gentlemen,
Prepare for revels.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Revels.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: Time hath several falls,
Griefs lift up joys, feasts put down funerals.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Come then my lords, my favours to you all,
The Duchess is suspected, foully bent,
I'll begin dukedom with her banishment?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Revels.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Ay, that's the word, we are firm yet,
Strike one strain more, and then we crown our wit.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.p: Well, have the fairest mark, — (So said the Duke when he begotten me,)
sp.l: And if I miss his heart or near about,
Then have at any a bastard scorns to be out.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.l: Notest thou that Spurio brother.

sp.speaker: And,
sp.l: Yes I note him to our shame.

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.p: He shall not live, his hair shall not grow much longer? in this time of revels tricks may be set a foot, seest thou yond new moon, it shall outlive the new Duke by much, this hand shall dispossess him, than we're mighty.
sp.l: A mask is treason's licence, that build upon?
'Tis murder's best face when a vizard's on.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Is't so, 'tis very good,
And do you think to be Duke then, kind brother:
I'll see fair play, drop one, and there lies tother.

div.stage: Enter Vindice and Hippolito, with Piero and other lords.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: My lords; be all of music, strike old griefs into other countries
That flow in too much milk, and have faint livers,
Not daring to stab home their discontents:
Let our hid flames break out, as fire, as lightning,
To blast this villainous dukedom: vexed with sin;
Wind up your souls to their full height again.

sp.speaker: Piero.
sp.l: How?
Which way?
Any way: our wrongs are such,
We cannot justly be revenge de too much.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: You shall have all enough: — revels are towards,
And those few nobles that have long suppressed you,
Are busied to the furnishing of a mask:
And do affect to make a pleasant tail on't,
The masking suits are fashioning, now comes in
That which must glad us all — we to take pattern
Of all those suits, the colour, trimming, fashion,
E'en to an undistinguished hair almost:
Then entering first, observing the true form,
Within a strain or two we shall find leisure,
To steal our swords out handsomely,
And when they think their pleasure sweet and good,
In midst of all their joys, they shall sigh blood.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Weightily, effectually, 3. before the tother maskers come.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: We're gone, all done and passed.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: But how for the Duke's guard?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Let that alone,
By one and one their strengths shall be drunk down,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: There are five hundred gentlemen in the action,
That will apply themselves, and not stand idle.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: O let us hug your bosoms.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come my lords,
Prepare for deeds, let other times have words.

div.stage: In a dumb show, the possessing of the young Duke. with all his nobles: then sounding music. A furnisht table is brought forth: then enters the Duke and his nobles to the banquot. A blazing-star appeareth.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: Many harmonious hours, and choicest pleasures,
Fill up the royal numbers of your years.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: My lords we're pleased to thank you? — though we know,
'Tis but your duty now to wish it so.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: That shine makes us all happy.

sp.speaker: 3. Noble
sp.l: His grace frowns?

sp.speaker: 2. Noble
sp.l: Yet we must say he smiles.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: I think we must.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: That foul-incontinent Duchess we have banished,
The bastard shall not live: after these revels
I'll begin strange ones; he and the stepsons,
Shall pay their lives for the first subsidies,
We must not frown so soon, else t'ad been now?

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: My gracious lord please you prepare for pleasure,
The mask is not far off.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: We are for pleasure,
Beshrew thee, what art thou? mad'st me start?
Thou hast committed treason, — a blazing star.

sp.speaker: 1, noble
sp.l: A blazing star, oh where my lord.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Spy out.

sp.speaker: 2. noble
sp.l: See, see, my lords, a wondrous-dreadful one.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I am not pleased at that ill-knotted fire,
That bushing-flaring star, — am not I Duke?
It should not quake me now: had it appeared,
Before it, I might then have justly feared,
But yet they say, whom art and learning weds:
When stars were locks, they threaten great-men's heads,
Is it so? you are read my lords.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: May it please your grace,
It shows great anger.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: That dos not please our grace.

sp.speaker: 2. Noble
sp.l: Yet here's the comfort my lord, many times.
When it seems most it threatens farthest off.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Faith and I think so too.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: Beside my lord,
You're gracefully established with the loves
Of all your subjects: and for natural death,
I hope it will be threescore years a coming.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: True, no more but threescore years.

sp.speaker: 1. Noble
sp.l: Fourscore I hope my lord:

sp.speaker: 2, noble
sp.l: And five-score, ay,

sp.speaker: 3, noble
sp.l: But 'tis my hope my lord, you shall ne'er die.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, these others I rebuke,
He that hopes so, is sittest for a Duke:
Thou shalt sit next me, take your places lords,
We're ready now for sports, let 'em set on.
You thing? we shall forget you quite anon!

sp.speaker: 3. Noble
sp.l: I hear 'em coming my lord.

div.stage: Enter the mask of revengers the two brothers, and two lords more.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Ah 'tis well,
Brothers, and bastard, you dance next in hell?

div.stage: The revengers dance? At the end, steal out their swords, and these four kill the four at the table, in their chairs, it thunders.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Mark, thunder?
Dost know thy cue, thou big-voiced crier?
Duke's groans, are thunders watchwords,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: So my lords, you have enough.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Come let's away, no lingering.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Follow, go?

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: No power is angry when the lustful die,
When thunderclaps, heaven likes the tragedy.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: O, o.

div.stage: Enter the other mask of intended murderers? Stepsons; bastard; and a fourth man, coming in dancing, the Duke recovers a little in voice, and groans, — calls a guard, treason.
At which they all start out of their measure, and turning towards the table, they find them all to be murdered.

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.l: Whose groan was that?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Treason, a guard.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How now? all murdered!

sp.speaker: Super.
sp.l: Murdered!
And those his nobles?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Here's a labour saved,
I thought to have sped him, 'sblood how came this.

sp.speaker: Spur.
sp.l: Then I proclaim myself, now I am Duke.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Thou Duke,! brother thou liest.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Slave so dost thou?
Base villain hast thou slain my lord and master.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Pistols, treason, murder, help, guard my lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Lay hold upon this traitors?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vind.
sp.l: Alas, the Duke is murdered.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And the nobles.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Surgeons, surgeons, — heart dos he breathe so long.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A piteous tragedy, able to wake,
An old-mans eyes bloodshot;

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Look to my lord the Duke a— vengeance throttle him.
Confess thou murderous and unhollowed man,
Didst thou kill all these?
None but the bastard I,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How came the Duke slain then;
We found him so,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: O villain,

sp.speaker: Vin,
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Those in the mask did murder us,

sp.speaker: Vin,
sp.l: La you now sir.
O marble impudence! will you confess now?
'Slud 'tis all false,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away with that foul monster,
Dipped in a prince's blood.
Heart 'tis a lie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him have bitter execution,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: New marrow no I cannot be expressed,
How fairs my lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Luss
sp.l: Farewell to all,
He that climbs highest has the greatest fall,
My tongue is out of office.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Air gentlemen, air,
Now thou'lt not prate on't, 'twas Vindice murdered thee,

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Murdered thy father.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And I am he tell nobody, so so, the Duke's departed,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It was a deadly hand that wounded him,
The rest, ambitious who should rule and sway,
After his death were so made all away,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: My lord was unlikely,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Now the hope,
Of Italy lies in your reverend years?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Your hair, will make the silver age again,
When there was fewer but more honest men,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: The burdens weighty and will press age down,
May I so rule that heaven nay keep the crown,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The rape of your good lady has been quited,
With death on death.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Just is the law above

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It was 〈…〉, I not hard of the like,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Twas all done for the best my lord,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: All for your grace's good ● we may be bold to speak it now,
'Twas somewhat witty carried though we say it.
'Twas we two murdered him,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You two?

sp.speaker: Vin,
sp.l: None else i'faith my lord nay 'twas well managed,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lay hands upon those villains.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How? on us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bear 'em two speedy execution,

sp.speaker: Vin,
sp.l: Heart waste not for your good my lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My good away with 'em such an old man as he,
You that would murder him would murder me,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is't come about;

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sfoot brother you begun,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: May not we set as well as the Duke's son,
Thou hast no conscience, are we not revenged?
Is there one enemy left alive amongst those?
'Tis time to die, when we are ourselves our foes.
When murders shut deeds close, this curse does seal 'em,
If none disclose 'em they themselves reveal'em !
This murder might have slept in tongueless brass,
But for ourselves, and the world died an ass;
Now I remember too, here was Piato.
Brought forth a knavish sentence once, no doubt (Said he) but time
Will make the murderer bring forth himself?
'Tis well he died, he was a witch,
And now my lord, since we are in for ever:
This work was ours which else might have been slipped,
And if we list we could have nobles clipped,
And go for 〈…〉 beggars, but we hate
〈…〉 we have enough,
〈…〉 mother turned our sister true,
〈◊〉 after a nest of Duke 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How subtly was that murder closed, bear up,
These tragic bodies, 'tis a heavy season:
〈◊〉 when their blood may wash away all treason.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
